reviewText:
Stick RPG 2 has two different sides to the game.  One side is a time management sim featuring wild goose chase quests, and the other side is a top down arcade brawler.  Both sides completely different from each other, and both are necessary to master to complete the game.

As a sim, your character has to make money through working jobs, gambling, and performing various tasks.  Doing favors (quests) for individuals will help you aquire different tools, which will ultimately lead you to the game goal items.  As for time management, you have to decide what jobs and tasks are worth your time to work to build up your bank and character stats.  You can also develop a love life interacting with potential mates.  You also sometimes have a choice on how to accomplish certian tasks, but there are very few choices offered throughout the entire game.

As a top down arcade brawler, it feels very similar to Hotline Miami, but everyone has a life bar, and you can't pick up weapons off the ground.  You can build weapons through quests, shop at the weapons store, or sometimes even win them as fight rewards.  Some battles will only allow you to fight with your fists, but there are also battle grounds where you can exploit all your weapons.

As far as the overall experience goes, it feels really unpolished and unfinished.  Prices of various items and services are very inflated, forcing you to spend a lot of time working jobs to develop a solid bank account.  It is also frusturating working a job and losing stats on a bad shift (on the job accidents, with no insurance options).  You also can have lucky days where you get a substantial bonus on your shift, but you can't adjust the odds in your favor for these events.  On a funny note, your strength stat will make your firearms stronger for some reason, and you have unlimited ammo, so running blindly with a machine gun or flame thrower on full auto is an acceptable tactic.  As fun as it is the first two or three times, it gets old really fast.

The game feels more like a prototype for something really awesome, but definitely lacks a lot of ambition, and needs to be tweaked.  I do recommend it to hobbyist level game designers who want ideas for implementation, but need some direction.  For everyone else, pick it up as cheap as you can (I got it for $1), and waste a good 4 to 6 hours before you give up on it.  It isn't so bad, it just isn't all that great either.

reviewText:
Stick RPG 2: Director's Cut is an expanded version of the flash game many of us have played. These types of flash games with collection quests, stat management, and simplistic combat are common on free game sites. It does seem as if the game has been fleshed out a bit, and more can be completed than in your standard flash game, but I don't believe enough has been added to justify the hefty price tag.

Gameplay is split into two major types. In the first, you run around the map, work for money, build your skills, and complete fetch quests. The second is combat, which is a top-down battle arena where you can switch weapons and attack by clicking. Niether is particularly deep or nuanced.

Graphics are the same that have been seen before in countless flash games. Nothing noteworthy. All characters are stick people.

The sounds consists of a constant background song, and some sound effects when you perform a task or fight. Very basic.

The writing is good enough to keep you interested for a bit, but there seem to be only a handful of quests to complete in the entire game. Gameplay is stretched out by the outrageous amounts of money or stats needed to obtain items. It would take hours and hours of mindless running back and forth and clicking to obtain some of the pricier items which are needed to continue quests.

Overall I cannot recommend Stick RPG 2. The game length is padded out by the ridiculous stat or money cost of some of the necessary quest items, which just hides the fact that there is not much to do in this game. Maybe it deserves a small price tag for the fact that it is a little longer than some of the free flash games, but it is nowhere near worth $20. Even if it was closer to the $5 range, I'd have a hard time recommending it because there is just not that much to do in it.

Grade: D+

reviewText:
I like this game because it triggered all my fond memories of addicting flash games from the early 2000's on Newgrounds.

It's not worth full price, I don't know if it's even worth the few dollars I put into it, but out of respect and nostalgia to the original Stick RPG and the good old times with similar flash games inspired by it- a couple bucks was fair to me personally.  It's worth mentioning that you can still play games like these for free on Newgrounds, so to drop actual money on this or not is totally your prerogative.

As for the gameplay you should know what you're in store for if you played the original Stick RPG.  You wake up, go somewhere in the city to click on a dialogue option repeatedly until you've increased your stat/money quota for the day, head home, sleep and repeat.  It's mind numbingly dull but oddly relaxing if you're in the right mindset.  This game hit the spot for me at a time where I was so record breakingly lazy that any and all other video games on Earth seemed like they required too much effort to play.

The resolution is terrible and there's no way to modify it.  Fullscreen mode looks ugly.  You have to go into this game wanting it really bad, or having brain damage like me, otherwise you're probably going to throw up.  You can look on the bright side, at least Stick RPG 2 a finalized product and not another Early Access game stuck in purgatory forever.

I think the creator and I would get along really well, his humor is as unfunny as mine.  I like that.

reviewText:
While this game is relatively short, there appears to have been a lot of work put into it. Some of the more advanced weapons are overpowered and make the battles too easy near the end of the game.

If you are a fan of grinding and leveling up, you will enjoy this game. Most quests are unlocked based on your level, so you're going to need to get yourself a job and improve your skills in order to make money to pay for your upgrades.

I was a bit disappointed with the ending, but others might find it appropriate. Personally, I was looking for something more.

There is replayability to this game, and you choose the way you complete the game. If you want to be an honest, friendly visitor who helps the law, or a rebel who gets a job as a pimp or hacker and works for the underworld, it's up to you.

I might start this game up again and give it another go, and see if there is anything differen that I might have missed.

Also, there are trophies to win based on acheivements, which add some more challenge to the game. Such as completing side quests, or earning a certain amount of money gambling.

All in all it's a decent game, and I recommend it.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
Okay, got this in a bundle today... I'm a sucker for weird RPGs and adventure games, so I gave it a try. Gosh, why do all the games I try these days have such horrible direction? I mean, it's looking like a trend for me: horrible short music playing in a loop (they have slightly less irritating music in some of the shops but it's only played in them!), controls are QWERTY only, meaning if you have an AZERTY keyboard you're screwed (unless you're eager to use AutoHotKey to fix the layout), or have to use the arrow keys, which of course isn't too practical if you're right-handed because you still have to use the mouse to click on dialog boxes -- and it gets worse: there's only a small area you can click to dismiss a dialog, so you have to navigate awkwardly with your keyboard, and then take your mouse and target an area to keep going. It feels like the UI is taken straight from my Windows 3.1 days. And I had Solitaire on it, which was way more entertaining.

I kept going for half an hour because I really wanted to give it a chance, but it's hard to find any qualities to the game. Combat is confusing, characters are only differentiated by their head color which is amusing but not particularly useful, I couldn't find the professor I was supposed to find at the beginning and I had no way to read a log reminding me of where/when he's supposed to be, and the map is huge, which is usually a good point but in this case I kept getting lost and there was no mini-map to help me. Plus, I actually spent 10 minutes running around the city until I realized running to its 'borders' would take me to another portion of it. Again, no visual clues...

Come to think of it, it isn't even that 'weird' a concept for a game, as it's inspired by other similar Flash games. The only weird thing in this is the implementation itself. And that's exactly where it should have kept to the basics.
Why, why, oh why?!

Review: Down UnderRating: 5/10

Stick RPG 2 is an interesting game to me. It was, at one point, a fun flash game you'd play when you had not much else to do, but then, they decided to release an extended edtion, not on Steam, for around 20 bucks, then release it on Steam later for the same price tag. Yet, I still found it interesting enough to pick up while on sale, a play through it finally.

The 2 in the title may not entice to get this game, because, why play a sequel when you've never played the game that came before? This isn't really the case as the first game didn't really have a story other than you dropping into a world, doing stuff, and getting extremely bored if you played a hacked version. Stick RPG 2 does have at least a little bit of a story line: you drop from your home and have to find a way back. The way you do this is by getting a job, so you can afford to get stronger, fight mobsters, gansters, etc., and collect all artifacts to unlock a portal so you can go home. The main issue with this, however, is that either you'll be stuck for a long time, or will finish this game in either a few hours or even less than that with a walkthrough. Why? Because this game has a lot of filler that gets in the way of the main goal.

Speaking of fighting, the fighting has been heavily improved from the first game, which had you using an RPG-like system that wasn't very good to begin with. Now, you aim, and click to fire, punch, and/or attack. The issue is, with this being a flash port, and not having been moved to another engine entirely, lag is a MASSIVE issue, and often times gets in the way while you're having a fight. Also, there is a boss fight in this game. I won't say anything about him other than he's incredibly weak, and, to add salt to an open wound, is the final and ONLY boss in the game.

Despite these glaring issues, this games also pretty fun. Doing jobs can be pretty fun, despite seeing the same lines of text over and over again, and, the whole role-playing thing works well. However, with this said, it's time I mention what this does different than the flash game: a couple of unlocked locations, ineffective cheats, and a full screen mode. I ♥♥♥♥ you not, those are the only extra things you get when you pay $20 for a normally free game. The cheats aren't even very good, and, plus of which, you need an X-GEN account to even save your game. This is sad, very, very sad.

In conclusion, I do not recommend you buy the Director's Cut version of SRPG2, unless you want a few practically useless features, and way more lag. The only thing stopping me from giving this a lower rating than 5 is the fact that Stick RPG 2 is still a fun game, despite it's many issues.

reviewText: This game is a lot of fun! I basically got this game for the nostalgic feels from Stick RPG 1. Here's the difference between those two games, Stick RPG 1 is 2 Dimensional and Stick RPG 2 is 2.5 Dimensional. But in Stick RPG 2 there are more areas to explore and WAY more stuff to do on this game!\n\nAll in all, I have to say this game is a lot of fun but don't buy this game at full price. Wait till it goes on sale and then get it. Anyways I definitely recommend this game if you're into a stickman's world.
